Navigation
Name Rascal/Expressions/Values/Tuple
Synopsis Tuple values.
Syntax < Exp1, Exp2, ... >
Types
Exp1 Exp2 ... < Exp1, Exp2, ... >
T1 T2 ... tuple[T1, T2, ... ]
Details Concatenation Equal FieldSelection GreaterThan GreaterThanOrEqual LessThan LessThanOrEqual NotEqual Subscription
Description A tuple is a sequence of elements with the following properties:
  • Each element in a tuple (may) have a different type.
  • Each element of a tuple may have a label that can be used to select that element of the tuple.
  • Each tuple is fixed-width, i.e., has the same number of elements.
Tuples are represented by the type tuple[T1 L1, T2 L2, ...], where T1, T2, ... are arbitrary types and L1, L2, ... are optional labels.

The following functions are provided for tuples:
  • Concatenation: Concatenate two tuple values.
  • Equal: Equality operator on tuple values.
  • FieldSelection: Select a field from a tuple by its field name.
  • GreaterThan: Greater than operator on tuple values.
  • GreaterThanOrEqual: Greater than or equal operator on tuple values.
  • LessThan: Less than operator on tuple values.
  • LessThanOrEqual: Less than or equal operator on tuple values.
  • NotEqual: Not equal operator on tuple values.
  • Subscription: Retrieve a tuple field by its index position.
Examples 
rascal>tuple[str first, str last, int age] P = <"Jo","Jones",35>;
tuple[str first,str last,int age]: <"Jo","Jones",35>
rascal>P.first;
str: "Jo"
rascal>P.first = "Bo";
tuple[str first,str last,int age]: <"Bo","Jones",35>
